members.affiliation: University of Greenwich, London, United Kingdom
members.name: Professor Stephen D. Thomas
members.biography:
<p>Stephen Thomas is Professor of Energy Policy in the Business School of the University of Greenwich, London, where he has led the energy research since 2001. He has a BSc in Chemistry (Bristol). He has worked as an independent energy policy researcher for 35 years. From 1979-2000, he was a member of the Energy Policy Programme at SPRU, University of Sussex and in 2001, he spent a year as a visiting researcher in the Energy Planning Programme at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro.</p>

<p>He has published extensively on reforms to electricity industries worldwide and on the corporate policies of energy companies. He was also a member of the team appointed by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to carry out the official economic due diligence study for the project to replace the Chernobyl nuclear power plant (1997). He was a member of an international panel appointed by the South African Department of Minerals and Energy to carry out a study of the technical and economic viability of a new design of nuclear power plant, the Pebble Bed Modular Reactor (2001-02). He was part of an independent team appointed by Eletronuclear (Brazil) to carry out an assessment of the economics of completing the Angra dos Reis 3 nuclear power plant (2002). He has published extensively on economics and policy on nuclear power.</p>

members.affiliation: University of Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal
members.name: Professor Carlos Antunes, PhD
members.biography: Carlos Henggeler Antunes received the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering (Optimization and Systems Theory) from the University of Coimbra, Portugal, in 1992. He is a Full Professor with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Coimbra, and the Director of the Institute for Systems Engineering and Computers (INESC) at Coimbra. His research interests include multiobjective optimization, metaheuristics, and energy planning with a focus on demand response. He is co-author of the book “Multiobjective Linear and Integer Programming” (Springer, 2016) and co-editor of the book “Energy and Behaviors” (Academic Press, 2019). He is senior editor of Energy Policy and editor of the EURO Journal on Decision Processes. He participated in more than forty R&D and consulting projects in the areas of energy systems and decision support systems.

members.affiliation: The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas, United States of America
members.name: Professor Varun Rai, PhD
members.biography: Dr. Varun Rai is the Walt and Elspeth Rostow Professor in the LBJ School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Austin, with a joint appointment in Mechanical Engineering. Through his interdisciplinary research at the interface of energy systems, complex systems, decision science, and public policy, he develops effective policy approaches to help accelerate the transition of the global energy system into a more sustainable and resilient one. He was a Global Economic Fellow in 2009. During 2013-2015 he was a Commissioner for the vertically-integrated electric utility Austin Energy and from 2019-2021 he served as director of the UT Austin Energy Institute. In 2016 the Association for Public Policy Analysis & Management (APPAM) awarded him the David N. Kershaw Award and Prize, which “was established to honor persons who, at under the age of 40, have made a distinguished contribution to the field of public policy analysis and management.” He received his Ph.D. and MS in Mechanical Engineering from Stanford University and a bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur.

members.affiliation: Chalmers University of Technology, Göteborg, Sweden
members.name: Professor Sonia Yeh, PhD
members.biography: Professor Sonia Yeh is Professor in Transport and Energy Systems in the Department of Space, Earth and Environment, Chalmers University of Technology Sweden, and the Vice Director of Area of Advance Energy at Chalmers. Her expertise is in energy economics and energy system modeling, alternative transportation fuels, sustainability standards, technological change, and consumer behavior and mobility. Throughout her work, she has advised and worked broadly with U.S. state and international advisers, policymakers, a wide range of stakeholder groups and academic researchers in developing climate policies toward reducing the environmental impacts and GHG emissions from transport. She served as Fulbright Distinguished Chair Professor in Alternative Energy Technology in 2016-2017 and received Håkan Frisinger Award by Volvo Research and Educational Foundations in 2019. She is an adjunct professor at the Department of Engineering and Public Policy, Carnegie Mellon University and a Senior Editor for Energy Policy journal since 2018.

members.affiliation: China University of Petroleum, Qingdao, PR China
members.name: Professor Peng Zhou, PhD
members.biography: Dr. Peng Zhou is a professor and Director of Institute for Energy Economics and Policy at China University of Petroleum (UPC), Qingdao, PR China. At UPC, he is also serving as the Vice President and the Dean of School of Economics and Management. Dr. Zhou received his Ph.D. degree in Industrial & Systems Engineering from the National University of Singapore (NUS), and then joined the Energy Studies Institute at NUS as a Fellow. Since 2009, he has been with Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics as a professor in management science and engineering. Dr. Zhou has conducted research in the broad area of energy and environmental economics, e.g. energy efficiency, emission trading, renewable energy investment, electric vehicle policy,  low-carbon development and performance evaluation methodologies. Among his honors and awards, Dr. Zhou was an awardee of the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars in China, a recipient of the ProSPER.Net-Scopus Young Researcher Award and the China MOE Award for Natural Science Research, and was continuously listed in the Elsevier Most Cited Chinese Researchers. In addition to be a Senior Editor of Energy Policy, he is also an editorial board member of several other peer-reviewed journals including Energy Economics, Energy, Energy Efficiency and Frontiers of Engineering Management.

As a PI, she has conducted 2 National Key R&D Program of China, 1 National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) key project, and many other projects. Based on which, she co-led a large collaborative team from Georgia Institute of Technology, Stony Brook University, the University of Adelaide, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Peking University and several other universities/ institutes to implement research on air pollution regional joint governance, renewable energy development, and energy-water nexus, energy-economy-environment (3E) System, etc. She has published more than 40 SCI/SSCI indexed papers on international academic journals including Nature Climate Change, One Earth, Water Research, Ecological Economics, etc.

members.biography:
Dr Lawrence Haar is a Senior Lecturer in Finance with Brighton University School of Business and Law. In addition to his academic career, Dr Haar has a broad range of experience in the private sector having been a Managing Director for Risk Management with major banks, energy and mining companies as well as Audit Assurance with Deloitte and financial regulation with the UK Authorities. He regularly appears in academic journals, such as International Review of Financial Analysis, Energy Policy, Energy Strategy Review and the publications of the Institute for Economic Affairs and the CATO Institute and the financial press, such as the Petroleum Economist.

members.affiliation: University of Pretoria, Department of Economics, Pretoria, South Africa
members.name: Professor Roula Inglesi-Lotz
members.biography:
Professor Inglesi-Lotz is a Professor in the Department of Economics in the Faculty of Economic and Management Sciences at the University of Pretoria. She completed her undergraduate studies in Greece at the University of Macedonia in Thessaloniki before she came to the University of Pretoria, where she completed her MCom in Economics (cum laude) and her doctorate in economics in 2011. 
Her research focuses on energy and environmental issues seeking answers to pressing issues associated with traditional ways of consuming and generating energy and investigating new and alternative solutions for higher efficiency in energy consumption and renewable fuels for generating energy. She is among the most prominent researchers in the field of economics, featured in the top 10 Economics authors of the African continent and consistently in the top 3 of South Africa based on the research of the last 10 years. She has published more than 70 academic papers in top international high-ranked journals within the last 10 years. She serves on the Editorial Boards of top international journals such as Energy Policy (JEPO), Energy Economics (ENECO) and Environmental Science and Pollution Research (ESPR).
Prof Inglesi-Lotz is the current Vice President for Membership and Affiliate relations of the International Association for Energy Economics. She is among the founding members of the South African Association for Energy Economics, where she served as President for four years. 
She has been a member of the South African Young Academy of Sciences (SAYAS) since 2017, where she served as a co-chair in 2019/20 and was the editor of the SAYAS PhD blog, giving a platform to the South African science youth to express their voice; and a member of the Global Young Academy (GYA) since 2018, where she served as a co-chair representing low – and middle – income countries for 2021/22. She was awarded the 2017 Women in Science prize in the Social sciences and humanities categories by the South African Department of Science and Technology (DST).
 <a href="https://sites.google.com/site/roulainglesilotzphd/">Editor's Personal Website</a>

Stephen P. A. Brown†
members.biography: <p>In Memoriam Announcement</p><p>It is with deep sadness that we inform you of the passing of Prof Stephen P.A. Brown, Editor-in-Chief of Energy Policy. Steve passed away on May 6, 2020. Steve became an editor in 2014, and has played a leading and crucial role in the development of Energy Policy in recent years. Steve was highly respected by all who interacted with him – he was precise, thoughtful, respectful, and graceful in every sense. We fondly remember Steve as a fine colleague, a scholar of great personal integrity, someone who was always supportive, collaborative, and generous with his time and advice. He will be dearly missed. An Obituary will be published in Energy Policy at a later date.</p><p>	The Editors and the Publisher</p>

members.affiliation: The University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States of America
members.name: Anna Alberini
members.biography:
Anna Alberini received her PhD in Economics from the University of California San Diego. She is currently a professor in the Department of Agricultural and Resources Economics at the University of Maryland, College Park. She teaches PhD-level econometrics courses, undergraduate statistics courses based on energy and environmental data, a course in the economics of climate change, and supervises numerous graduate and undergraduate research projects. She is an energy and environmental economist with a major focus on the economics of health and safety and non-market valuation. Her energy economics research focuses on residential energy demand, energy efficiency decisions and consequences of such decisions, policies targeted as shaping residential energy demand, and on vehicle fuel economy and driving decisions. Her work has appeared in the Energy Journal, Energy Economics, Energy Efficiency, JEEM, the Review of Economics and Statistics, the Journal of Health Economics, and other journals. Alberini has served two stints on the Science Advisory Board for Environmental Economics to the US Environmental Protection Agency and is currently the chair of the American Statistical Association committee that advises the US Energy Information Administration. She is also a member of the Editorial Board of The Energy Journal, of the International Advisory Board of Energy Policy, and an associate editor of Energy Efficiency.
 <a href="https://agnr.umd.edu/about/directory/anna-alberini">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, Colorado, United States of America
members.name: Douglas J. Arent
members.biography:
Arent has worked in research on energy and sustainability for more than 30 years, publishing extensively on topics including clean energy, renewable energy, power systems, natural gas, and the intersection of science and public policy.

In addition to his NREL responsibilities, Arent is a distinguished fellow of the World Economic Forum, and a senior visiting fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Arent is also a member of the Keystone Energy Board and an external fellow at the Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs’ Center on Global Energy Policy and the Andlinger Center for Energy and the Environment at Princeton University. He is the editor in chief for Renewable Energy Focus and is on the editorial board for the journal Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews.

Previously, Arent served on the American Academy of Arts and Sciences Steering Committee on Social Science and the Alternative Energy Future, and he was a member of the National Research Council Committee to Advise to U.S. Global Change Research Program. He also served on the advisory boards for the Post-Carbon Transition Project at the Institute for New Economic Thinking at Oxford University, U.K., and the Energy Academy of Europe, Netherlands.

At NREL, he previously served as the deputy associate laboratory director for the Scientific Computing and Energy Analysis directorate, the founding executive director of the Joint Institute for Strategic Energy Analysis, and the director for the Strategic Energy Analysis Center and the Integrated Applications Center. Arent was a coordinating lead author for the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. He has been a member of the Policy Subcommittee of the National Petroleum Council Study on Prudent Development of North America Natural Gas and Oil Resources, the National Academy of Sciences Panel on Limiting the Magnitude of Future Climate Change (2008–2010), and the Executive Council of the U.S. Association of Energy Economists.

Arent has a doctorate from Princeton University, a Masters of Business Administration from Regis University, and a Bachelor of Science from Harvey Mudd College in California.
 <a href="https://www.nrel.gov">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia, United States of America
members.name: Marilyn Brown
members.biography:
Marilyn A. Brown is a Professor in the School of Public Policy at the Georgia Institute of Technology, where she created and directs the Climate and Energy Policy Lab. Prior to joining Georgia Tech, she worked for 22 years at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, where she led national evaluations of weatherization and energy innovation programs, conducted several national climate change mitigation studies, and became a leader in the analysis and interpretation of energy futures in the U.S. Her research focuses on the design and modeling of energy and climate policies, with an emphasis on the electric utility industry, the size and nature of the “energy efficiency gap”, and resources on the customer side of the meter where the social sciences and behavior economics are so important.<br> <br>From 2010 through 2017, she served on the Board of Directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the largest public power provider in the U.S., where her efforts helped put the agency on track to reduce its CO2 emissions in 2020 by 60% relative to 2005. She has authored more than 250 publications and six books. Among her honors and awards, she is a co-recipient of the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize for co-authorship of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report on <em>Mitigation of Climate Change</em>. She has served on eight committees of the U.S. National Academies and currently is in her second term as a member of the U.S. Department of Energy’s Electricity Advisory Committee, where she is Vice Chair of the Smart Grid Subcommittee.
 <a href="http://www.spp.gatech.edu/faculty/marilynbrown/">Editor's Personal Website</a></br></br>

members.affiliation: Council on Energy Environment and Water, New Delhi, India
members.name: Vaibhav Chaturvedi
members.biography:
Vaibhav is an economist who leads the Council on Energy, Environment and Water's (CEEW's) work on Low-Carbon Pathways. His research focuses on energy and climate change mitigation policy issues, especially those impacting India, within the integrated assessment modelling framework of the Global Change Assessment Model (GCAM). Vaibhav’s recent work includes modelling for informing India's state level policies, net-zero scenarios for India, studies on pathways and policies for achieving India’s Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and Mid-Century Strategies within the context of sustainable development and national priorities, the climate policy–energy–water nexus, transportation energy and emission scenarios, HFC emission scenarios and mitigation policy, and nuclear energy scenarios for India.<br>Prior to joining the Council, he was a Postdoctoral Research Associate at the Joint Global Change Research Institute/ Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, USA. He has been actively involved in global model comparison exercises like the Asian Modelling Exercise (AME) and the Energy Modelling Forum (EMF). He is a part of various Government of India's committees related to energy and climate policy.
 <a href="https://www.ceew.in/vaibhav-chaturvedi">Editor's Personal Website</a></br>

members.name: Aad Correlje
members.biography:
Aad Correljé is Associate Professor of Economics of Infrastructures at the Faculty Technology, Policy and Management (TBM), TU Delft. Aad Correljé graduated in Political Sciences International Relations at the University of Amsterdam (1988). He defended (1994) his PhD thesis, The Spanish Oil Industry: Structural Change and Modernisation at the Economic Faculty/Tinbergen Institute at the Erasmus University in Rotterdam. He is a research fellow with the Clingendael International Energy Programme (CIEP). He is a Member of the Dutch Mining Council since 2013 and of the Editorial Board of the journal Energy Policy since 2002. His research involves an institutional economics approach to public policy, regulation, and private strategy development in infrastructure-bound sectors in energy and water. Correljé has published extensively on the evolution of the European and US natural gas markets and is involved on a regular basis in media coverage on energy and sustainability issues.
 <a href="https://www.tudelft.nl/en/tpm/our-faculty/departments/values-technology-and-innovation/people/associate-professors/dr-af-aad-correlje">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
members.name: Debra J. Davidson
members.biography: <p>Debra J. Davidson is Professor of Environmental Sociology in the Department of Resource Economics and Environmental Sociology at the University of Alberta, having received her Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin (1998). Her key areas of teaching and research include impacts and adaptation to climate change, and crises and transitions in food and energy systems. Dr. Davidson is President of the Research Committee on Environment and Society in the International Sociological Association, and she was a Lead Author in Working Group II of the Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change’s 5th Assessment Report. Her work is featured in several journals, including <em>Science, Nature, Global Environmental Change, British Journal of Sociology, </em>and <em>International Sociology, </em>among others. She is co-editor of <em>The Oxford Handbook of Energy and Society </em>(2018) and <em>Environment and Society: Concepts and Challenges </em>(Palgrave 2018), and co-author of <em>Challenging Legitimacy at the Precipice of Energy Calamity </em>(Springer, 2011).</p>

members.name: Nick Eyre
members.biography:
Nick Eyre is Professor of Energy and Climate Policy in the Environmental Change Institute of the University of Oxford. He is currently Director of the Centre for Research into Energy Demand Solutions (CREDS), which is UK Research and Innovation’s major centre for research on energy use. He is an acting Co-Director of the University of Oxford’s new Zero-carbon Energy Research Oxford (the ZERO Institute). 
Nick has been a Lead Author and Review Editor in the last two cycles of the IPCC Mitigation Report. He is a member of the Science Expert Group of the Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy and scientific advisor on climate change to Oxford City Council. 
Nick has a doctorate in nuclear physics from the University of Oxford. From 2007 to 2017, he was a Co-Director of the UK Energy Research Centre, and before that Director of Strategy at the Energy Saving Trust.
 <a href="https://www.eci.ox.ac.uk/people/neyre.html">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: Beihang University, Beijing, China
members.name: Ying Fan
members.biography:
Dr. Ying Fan is a Professor and the Dean of the School of Economics and Management at Beihang University and the Director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research, which is a joint research center sponsored by CAS, CNPC and Beihang University. She has received important awards such as Changjiang Scholar, National Science Grant for Distinguished Young Scientists, CAS Hundred Talents Program, and Special Government Allowance sponsored by the State Council. She is currently the Vice President for Academic Affairs of the International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE), Vice President of the Chinese Society of Optimization, Overall Planning and Economic Mathematics (OOPEM), and President of the Chinese Society of Low Carbon Development Management. She has long term research experience in the field of energy economics and management, completed valuable works on Energy-Environment-Economy systems modeling and policy analysis. She has published more than 200 peer reviewed journal papers. Before joining the Editorial Board of Energy Policy, she has been an editorial board member of the Energy Journal and the area editor of Computers and Industrial Engineering.
 <a href="http://shi.buaa.edu.cn/fanying/en/index.htm">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: University of Sao Paulo, SAO PAULO, Brazil
members.name: José Goldemberg
members.biography: Professor José Goldemberg earned his Ph.D. in Physical Sciences from the University de São Paulo in 1954, where he held the position of Full Professor in the Engineering School’s Physics Department. He was Rector of the University from 1986 to 1991. A Member of the Brazilian Academy of Sciences, he has served as the President of Brazilian Association for the Advancement of Science and President of the Energy Company of the State of São Paulo (CESP). Between 1990 and 1992, he was Brazil’s Secretary of State for Science and Technology and Minister of State for Education. Over the years, he did research and taught at the University of Illinois, Stanford University of Paris (Orsay) and Princeton University. From 1998 to 2000, he served as Chairman of the World Energy Assessment. More recently, between 2002 and 2006, he was Secretary for the Environment of the State of São Paulo. He has authored many technical papers and books on Nuclear Physics, Sustainable Development and Energy. In 2007 Time honoured him as one of its “Heroes of the Environment”. In 2007 he was awarded the “KPCB Prize for Greentech Policy Innovators”. In 2008 he was awarded the Blue Planet Prize 2008 of the Asahi Glass Foundation (Japan). In 2010 he received the “Trieste Science Prize” of the Third World Academy of Sciences and in 2013 “Lifetime Achievement Award” from the Zayed Future Energy Prize. He is presently Professor Emeritus of the University of São Paulo.

He has also been a Guest Editor of various special issues of international peer-reviewed journals and Editor of many handbooks.

members.name: Mark Jaccard
members.biography:
Mark is a professor since 1986 at Simon Fraser University, interrupted in 1992-97 while he served as Chair and CEO of the British Columbia Utilities Commission. His PhD is in energy economics from the University of Grenoble, and his research focus is the design and application of energy-economy models for assessing climate policies. Internationally, Mark has served on the IPCC, the China Council for International Cooperation on Environment and Development, and the Global Energy Assessment, and domestically on the National Roundtable on the Environment and the Economy and the Canadian Institute for Climate Choices. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada and the CD Howe Institute, and in 2009 was named British Columbia Academic of the Year. He is one of eight professors at Simon Fraser University awarded the title, Distinguished Professor, and currently directs the School of Resource and Environmental Management. He has published over 100 academic papers. In 2006, his Sustainable Fossil Fuels won the Donner Prize for top policy book in Canada. His latest book is The Citizen’s Guide for Climate Success.
 <a href="http://markjaccard.blogspot.com/">Editor's Personal Website</a>

members.affiliation: Tufts University Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Medford, Massachusetts, United States of America
members.name: Amy Jaffe
members.biography:
Amy Myers Jaffe is Research Professor and Managing Director of the Climate Policy Lab. She was formerly the David M. Rubenstein Senior Fellow for Energy and the Environment and Director of the Program on Energy Security and Climate Change at the Council on Foreign Relations.<br><br><br>A leading expert on global energy policy and sustainability, Jaffe previously served as senior advisor for sustainability at the Office of the Chief Investment Officer at the University of California, Regents and as executive director for energy and sustainability at University of California, Davis where she led research on low or zero carbon fuels and transportation policy. Jaffe has taught energy policy, business, and sustainability courses at Rice University, University of California, Davis, and Yale University. Jaffe is widely published, including as co-author of Oil, Dollars, Debt and Crises: The Global Curse of Black Gold, with Mahmoud El-Gamal.<br><br><br>Her forthcoming book Energy's Digital Future: Harnessing Innovation for American Resilience and National Security will be published by Columbia University Press in 2021. She is chair of the steering committee of the Women in Energy Initiative at Columbia University's Center on Global Energy policy.<br><br><br>A frequent media commentator, Jaffe is president of the U.S. Association of Energy Economics and holds a Senior Fellow award from that organization for her career contributions to the field of energy economics. 
 <a href="http://www.amymyersjaffe.com/">Editor's Personal Website</a></br></br></br></br></br></br></br></br></br>

members.affiliation: ESCP Business School - London, London, United Kingdom
members.name: Michael Jefferson
members.biography: Michael Jefferson studied at University College, Oxford and then the London School of Economics, before going into an economics consultancy, an industrial policy body, and then becoming Chief Economist of The Royal Dutch / Shell Group. He spent nearly 20 years at Shell in various roles, from Head of Planning in Europe to Director of Oil Supply and Trading, and Head of Oil Pricing. He then spent ten years as Deputy Secretary-General of the World Energy Council, where he began working with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change as Contributing Author, Lead Author, Editorial Reviewer and Expert Reviewer, culminating in his receipt of the IPCC‘s certificate for his contributions to their award of the Nobel Peace Prize in December 2007. He has also written extensively on energy policy, including contributions to various UN bodies, and was for many years involved with the World Renewable Energy Network and Congresses as Chairman of its Policies Committee. Alongside his work in business he has written several books in the fields of energy and economics; contributed to books on economic and social history; and written or co-authored many peer-reviewed papers in the energy and environmental field. He became an academic in 2007 annd is a Professor at ESCP Business School. Michael was Senior Editor of Energy Policy between 2013 and 2019.

members.biography:
Professor Qiang Ji is deputy director of Institute of System Analysis and Management in Institutes of Science and Development, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ISDCAS). He presides the program supported by Excellent Young Scientists Fund of National Natural Science Foundation of China and is granted the Excellent Member by Youth Innovation Promotion Association of CAS. He engaged in the research of energy and climate finance, energy strategic management, big data and energy prediction. He is the co-founder of China Energy Finance Network, Vice President of International Society for Energy Transition Studies and Society for the Studies of Climate Finance. He was a founding editor of Journal of Climate Finance and served as senior editors, associate editors and guest editors for a series of energy and financial journals. He published more than 150 SCI/SSCI indexed articles in peer-reviewed journals and was selected into Clarivate's List of Highly Cited Researcher in 2021 and 2022 and the World’s Top 2% Scientists List published by Stanford University since 2020.

items.intro:
<p>The energy transition and the electrification of the heating and transport sectors will require a more active participation of the demand side to balance fluctuating renewable energy supply with demand and reduce the need for grid expansion. In addition, the energy crisis has revealed important shortcomings in the current design of electricity tariffs. Customers paying real-time prices have experienced excessive bill increases that led to regulatory interventions in the form of compensations. Customers on fixed-price contracts, on the other hand, had insufficient incentives to reduce their load.</p>
<p>Future-proof electricity tariffs should provide a solution to all these challenges. They should protect customers from excessive price peaks but still retain incentives for demand response and enable customers to specify the amount of flexibility which they are able to provide and ensure that this flexibility is used optimally. In addition, the regulation for retailers needs to be revised, to enable competition without undermining the incentives to hedge against increasingly volatile prices.</p>
items.title: Future Electricity Tariffs

items.intro: <p>There is an urgent demand for research supporting the development of new policy frameworks for energy saving and conservation. Artificial Intelligence and Data Science advances are augmenting the ability to make decisions by leveraging the power of advanced analytics and collective intelligence. It is now possible to understand how people are being made aware of new energy solutions and their advantages for environmental sustainability. Text mining and social network analysis can support the development and diffusion of new energy policies, technologies, and sustainable business strategies. We solicit original research on big data methods and tools to support the decisions of policymakers and companies operating in the energy ecosystem. </p>
items.title: Boosting the clean energy transition through data science

items.intro: <p>Wind power has a vast potential to provide energy services. It is estimated that utilising just 20% of the global technical potential of wind power would fulfil the world’s entire energy requirements. This article assesses the potential sites for wind farms at a scale across Europe and assesses their potential efficiency as well as limitations, risks and drawbacks.</p>
items.description: <p>Wind power has a vast potential to provide energy services. It is estimated that utilising just 20% of the global technical potential of wind power would fulfil the world’s entire energy requirements.<br><br>In order to exploit this potential for future energy policies, research and planning, it is necessary to produce a comprehensive and accurate assessment of potential sites for wind farms at a scale that can assess their limitations, risks and drawbacks as well as potential energy production. An <strong><a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.enpol.2019.06.064">article </a></strong>published in Elsevier's journal <em>Energy Policy</em> does this for onshore wind power in Europe.<br><br>The study by Peter Enevoldsen from the Centre for Energy Technologies at Aarhus University in Denmark, and his colleagues, aims to do this for the continent of Europe. It uses spatial analysis conducted through the geographical information system (GIS) – satellites and public databases relating to electricity, planning and other dimensions – to produce maps incorporating all the constraints. These were of three basic types: infrastructure (roads, waterways, airports and railways), buildings (residential, industrial, etc.), and protected areas (parks, monuments, etc.). The authors acknowledge that not all the land that avoided these constraints would be available to site wind farms, however. For example, land might be privately owned, or assigned for other use, or there might be strong public opposition to building wind farms on it.<br><br>The authors conclude that potential onshore wind energy production in Europe actually exceeds the projected total global energy requirements for 2050. They calculate that there is 52.5 TW of untapped onshore wind power potential in Europe, and especially in some of the larger non-EU countries such as Norway, Russia and Turkey. This figure is higher than previous studies, in part because they incorporate the higher production capacity of current technology, and in part because they are particularly liberal about which land can be used for wind farms. However, they were also using the most accurate and highest resolution data.<br><br><strong>Article details</strong>:<br>“<a href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.enpol.2019.06.064">How much wind power potential does Europe have? Examining European wind power potential with an enhanced socio-technical atlas</a>", Enevoldsen, P. et al. <em>Energy Policy </em>(2019) </p>
items.title: Mapping the potential for onshore wind farms in Europe

items.intro: <p>Nearly three billion people still rely on harmful, smoky cooking fuels such as wood, dung and kerosene. Despite concerted efforts to introduce cleaner methods, the transition to clean household fuel remains slow and a huge acceleration will be needed if the UN’s <a href="https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/sdg7" data-cke-saved-href="https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/sdg7">Sustainable Development Goal 7</a>, which calls for ‘affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all’, is to be met by 2030.</p>
items.title: A blueprint for clean cooking

items.intro: <p>The world of 1974 in which the <a href="https://www.iea.org/" data-cke-saved-href="https://www.iea.org/">International Energy Agency</a> (IEA) was set up was very different to that of today. The IEA was established after the 1970s oil crisis to regulate the supply of oil to large oil-consuming countries, particularly during future crises, and it has generally been viewed as the predominant international organisation in global energy. </p>
items.title: Modernise or die? The International Energy Agency adapts to a new world

items.intro: <p>Improvements to cars and small trucks in the US have doubled vehicle fuel economy since 1975. An <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301421520302627?via%3Dihub" data-cke-saved-href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301421520302627?via%3Dihub">article </a>published in Elsevier’s <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301421520302627?via%3Dihub" data-cke-saved-href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301421520302627?via%3Dihub">Energy Policy </a>in April 2020 estimates that this has led to savings of two trillion gallons of fuel, 17 billion tonnes of CO2 emissions and 4.9 trillion dollars.</p>
items.title: Trillions of gallons and dollars saved by vehicle improvements in the US

items.intro: <p>Three researchers from Germany’s <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.isi.fraunhofer.de/en.html" target="_blank" data-cke-saved-href="https://www.isi.fraunhofer.de/en.html">Fraunhofer Institute for Systems and Innovation Research</a> and Russia's <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.hse.ru/en/" target="_blank" data-cke-saved-href="https://www.hse.ru/en/">Higher School of Economics</a> have proposed a methodological framework for comparing and assessing how European countries are progressing towards the EU’s 2050 low carbon targets.</p>
items.title: The EU has set low carbon targets for 2050 – Will they be met?

items.intro: <p>The concept of 'energy poverty', defined simply as the inability to heat the home to an acceptable level, was first introduced in the UK in the 1970s. However, this concept has only recently been taken on board by policymakers. Instead, general measures of deprivation are used as a proxy, with energy-specific interventions targeted to areas classed simply as 'deprived'.</p>
items.title: What does it mean to be energy poor in England?

items.intro: <p>Photovoltaic Solar Modules, thought to be one of the cleanest forms of energy, has dramatically increased in popularity in recent years due to a rapid reduction in the cost of this technology. In this article, researchers based at Massachusetts Institute of Technology carry out a detailed analysis of the reasons behind this cost reduction.</p>
items.title: Explaining the plummeting cost of solar modules

items.intro: <p>Policy analysts in Finland contend that the term "renewable energy" should be ditched.</p>
items.title: The problem with talking about renewables

items.intro:
<p>
	Some commentators have observed recently that vast quantities of oil and gas must remain in the ground because of anticipated action on climate change consequently affecting fall in share value, investments and the stability of the financial system however, new research published in "Energy Policy" suggests that there is little basis for this concern.</p>
items.title: Stranded oil of Erewhon

items.intro:
<p>
	A team of researchers in the US has evaluated the likelihood of one or more foreign oil disruptions over the next 10 years, and estimates an approximately 80% probability of a significant disruption, with a region comprising the Persian Gulf countries (excluding Saudi Arabia) identified as the most risky area.</p>
items.title: Updated assessment of oil market disruption risks

items.intro:
<p>
	Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) holds the promise of cheap, flexible and fast-responding energy storage through the use of electric vehicle (EV) batteries. Unfortunately, infrastructure, battery degradation and consumer awareness are only some of the challenges to a faster development of this technology.</p>
items.title: Policy mechanisms for accelerated diffusion of Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) in Nordic region
